clusters.title: Homeschool Success
clusters.description: Home-educated students consistently outperform public school students, scoring 15-25 percentile points higher on standardized tests. Studies indicate 78-87% of homeschooled students perform significantly better than those in institutional schools. They also achieve notably higher scores on college entrance exams, with homeschool graduates surpassing public school peers by 130 points overall, including 68 points higher in reading, 10 points in math, and 66 points in writing.

clusters.title: Homeschooling Surge
clusters.description: In 2020, an estimated 2.5 million students were homeschooled in the US, comprising 5.2% of all school-aged children. This reflects a significant increase from 2003, when 1.1 million were homeschooled. Registrations increased by 20% from 2019 to 2021, and the proportion of homeschooled students rose from 3.4% in 2019 to 9% in fall 2020, indicating a notable surge in homeschooling.

merged_facts.merged_content: The number of homeschooled children in the United States doubled from 1.1 million in 2003 to 2.3 million in 2020, and remained at 2.3 million in March 2021.

clusters.title: Parent Concerns
clusters.description: A significant majority of parents, 69%, noted their children spent over 3 hours daily on screens. This excessive screen time has led to considerable concern, with 95% of parents worried about potential eyesight issues. Additionally, 17.6% of students are suspected to have emotional or behavioral problems, indicating potential negative impacts of screen usage.
